title: Galician League (A Coruña)
text:
The Galician League of <a href="A%20Coru%C3%B1a">A Coruña</a> ("Liga Gallega" in both <a href="Spanish%20language">Spanish</a> and <a href="Galician%20language">Galician language</a>) was a <a href="Liberalism">liberal</a> and <a href="Galicianism%20%28Galicia%29">Galician regionalist</a> political group founded in 1897 in <a href="A%20Coru%C3%B1a">A Coruña</a> by the participants in the <a href="Galicianism%20%28Galicia%29">regionalist</a> club A Cova Céltiga ("The Celtic Cave"), with its headquarters in the Carré Aldao library; chaired by <a href="Manuel%20Murgu%C3%ADa">Manuel Murguía</a> and directed by a committee consisting of <a href="Manuel%20Lugr%C3%ADs%20Freire">Manuel Lugrís Freire</a>, <a href="Ux%C3%ADo%20Carr%C3%A9%20Aldao">Uxío Carré Aldao</a> and Salvador Golpe.
History.
In 1898 the statutes of the League were drafted, entirely in <a href="Galician%20language">Galician language</a>. Waldo Álvarez Insua was elected as the president of the organization in 1899. It was one of the currents in which the <a href="Galician%20Regionalist%20Association">Galician Regionalist Association</a> bifurcated. The Galician League of <a href="A%20Coru%C3%B1a">A Coruña</a> was <a href="Liberalism">liberal</a>, while the <a href="Galician%20League%20%28Santiago%20de%20Compostela%29">Galician League of Santiago de Compostela</a> was ideologically <a href="Conservatism">conservative</a>. The league demanded autonomy for <a href="Galiza">Galiza</a>, conducting in 1897 a signature collection to ask for the same autonomy than <a href="Cuba">Cuba</a> and <a href="Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</a>.
After 1900 the League had little activity, but survived until 1907. The official newspaper of the organization was the bilingual weekly Revista Gallega, directed by <a href="Galo%20Salinas">Galo Salinas</a>. Thanks to an initiative of the League, and specially of <a href="Galo%20Salinas">Galo Salinas</a>, in 1904 a monument to the <a href="Martyrs%20of%20Carral">Martyrs of Carral</a> was built in the town of <a href="Carral">Carral</a>.
